discovery.description: An adversary may attempt to get detailed information about the operating system and hardware, including version, patches, hotfixes, service packs, and architecture.
Adversaries may interact with the Windows Registry to gather information about the system, configuration, and installed software.

command-and-control.description: Adversaries may communicate using application layer protocols associated with web traffic to avoid detection/network filtering.

defense-evasion.technique_name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Software Packing
defense-evasion.description: Adversaries may perform software packing or virtual machine software protection to conceal their code.

Adversaries may interact with the Windows Registry to hide configuration information within Registry keys, remove information as part of cleaning up, or as part of other techniques to aid in persistence and execution.

execution.description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution.

persistence.technique_name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
persistence.description: Adversaries may achieve persistence by adding a program to a startup folder or referencing it with a Registry run key.

privilege-escalation.technique_name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
privilege-escalation.description: Adversaries may achieve persistence by adding a program to a startup folder or referencing it with a Registry run key.
